revisions.rev:
{{Cleanup|date=November 2008}} {{Infobox comic strip |title= Frazz |image=<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Frazzcomic (Frazz himself).png]] --> |caption= Frazz, the title character |author= [[Jef Mallett]] |url= http://gocomics.com/frazz |rss= |atom= |status= Running |first= 2 April 2001 |last= |syndicate= [[United Media|United Feature Syndicate]] |publisher= [[Andrews McMeel Publishing, LLC|Andrews McMeel Publishing]] |genre= |rating= |preceded by= |followed by= }}
'''''Frazz''''' is a [[print syndication|syndicated]] [[comic strip]] by [[Jef Mallett]] that, on the surface, is about [[janitor|school custodian]] Edwin "Frazz" Frazier and the school where he works, but which, according to Mallett, is really about discovery.<ref name = Bass/> The strip debuted on 2 April 2001.<ref>[http://www.allbusiness.com/services/business-services-miscellaneous-business/4691917-1.html "Fifth anniversary nears for "Frazz'", ''Editor & Publisher'' (March 23, 2006)]</ref>
==Style and theme== Mallett has explained that the strip is about discovery, and not merely learning. Frazz's job is just the surface. He reads everything from [[John Milton|Milton]] to [[Hiaasen]] to bike racing magazines, he writes, he races, heâs an athlete, and heâs a songwriter, discovering the value of a day job. When songwriting started going well, he kept his custodian job because it was the perfect environment for discovery through the energy and interest of the students.<ref name=Bass>[http://www.lansingbusinessmonthly.com/article_read.asp?articleID=4314 Bass, Adrian, "Joy in learning, joy in work" ''Greater Lansing Business Monthly'' (April 2009)]</ref> Many of the characters are based on his childhood experiences at school, and at home as the child of an educator.<ref name = Enquirer/> Frazz is, at least attitudinally, based on Mallett himself.<ref>[http://www.detroitnews.com/article/20090416/OPINION03/904160410/1383/OPINION0308 Rubin, Neal, "Lansing cartoonist's talks with troops rewarding", ''Detroit News'' (April 16, 2009)]</ref> During a 1996 book tour of schools to promote a children's book he wrote and illustrated, Mallett noticed that the kids wouldn't quiet down for their teachers or principals, but would for the school janitor; he or she was "the man", existing on a separate plane between the students and adults.<ref name = Guzman/>
==Recurring characters== '''Frazz''' — The [[eponymous]] character, Edwin Frazier<ref name = Watson>[http://detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090126/ENT05/901260304/1422/ENT05 Watson, Ursula, "Smart 'Frazz' joins News's comics page" ''Detroit News'' (January 26, 2009)]</ref> is a 29-year-old songwriter who took a job as janitor of Bryson Elementary (He mentions that he got out of third grade 21 years previous to the strip's beginning). Later, he says that he is barely thirty, probably meaning that he ages in real time. Mallett describes him as "the voice of reason, the voice of experience and, frequently, the voice of temptation."<ref name = Bass/> He took the job because his songwriting career wasn't going well, but then several of his songs became major hits. Now independently wealthy, he keeps his job as janitor because he can.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-04-03/ Frazz 04-03-2001]</ref> His daily interactions with the students and faculty reveal insight into an unimaginable number of topics: books, music, pop culture, art, history, and many more. A true [[Polymath|Renaissance man]], Frazz is always ready to teach children and adults more about the world around them. Because he doesn't look down on them, the students look up to him, and he also has the respect of the adults (with the possible exception of Mrs. Olsen, who remembers what a handful he was when he was in third grade.<ref name = Guzman/>) Drawing inspiration from his daily school life, his songs soon become extremely popular. Frazz loves triathlons, bicycling, jogging, swimming, basketball, songwriting, and talking with the students. However, among the students, he seems to have a spot in his heart for Caulfield especially, as he is always spurring him to mischief (often unintentionally), and makes excuses for Caulfield's "bored genius" behavior. He also seems to always clean the detention room where Caulfield spends a good bit of his time. He has a pet guinea pig which he rescued from Mrs. Olsen's classroom and named it "Lyle" after [[Lyle Lovett]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2001-04-30&DateBefore=2001-05-05&Order=d.DateStrip+DESC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=14&y=9 Frazz Apr 30-May 5, 2001]</ref> It is revealed that Frazz has a sister who is a nurse. It is also revealed that he wore sweaters all through high school, and he says that they were reminiscent of Bill Cosby's often-colorful and oddly-patterned sweaters. This is part of his streak of bad fashion savvy, as he also would have bought a Hawaiian shirt with a pattern of dogs playing poker on it.
'''Caulfield''' — An eight-year-old named by his parents after [[J. D. Salinger]]'s [[Holden Caulfield]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VA&p_theme=va&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FAD78EC6E0A4009&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D |title=New comic strip debuts in today's Advocate |author=Pat Hathcock |work=Victoria Advocate |date=2003-05-05 |accessdate=2008-01-04 |format=fee required }}</ref> Caulfield tried to convince Mrs. Olsen that he was from a disadvantaged background, but his father is finishing his PhD in pharmacology, and his mother is a civil engineer.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-08-23/ Frazz 8/23/2001]</ref> Mallett regards Caulfield as "the hero of the strip... He wonât give up that joy of learning for the sake of a test score, for quiet approval, for the easy A".<ref name =Bass/> Caulfield is a handful. He is a genius, but hates school because it fails to challenge him.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-04-04/ Frazz 04-04-2001]</ref> He spends a lot of time in detention for speaking out in class, but whiles away the hours discussing books or logic with Frazz. His fresh perspective on the world brings interesting, often startling revelations to the comic. Caulfield chooses a literature-themed costume every [[Halloween]], often stumping most of the teachers, but which Frazz invariably gets. Mrs. Olsen decides one year to glean all of the books Caulfield has checked out over the year from the library. She says it's a good plan until Frazz mentions that it "narrows it down to triple digits." She refines the statement, saying it's a good plan, not a foolproof one. Caulfield's costumes have included: *Scout from ''[[To Kill a Mockingbird]]''<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-10-31/ Frazz 10-31-2001]</ref> *Santiago from ''[[The Old Man and the Sea]]''<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2002-10-31/ Frazz 10/31/2002]</ref> *[[Dorian Gray]]<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2003-10-31/ Frazz 10-31-2003]</ref> *The Frog from ''[[The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County]]''<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2004-10-30/ Frazz 10-30-2004]</ref> *The Greek god [[Zeus]]<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2005-10-31/ Frazz 10-31-2005]</ref> *[[Chief Bromden]] from ''[[One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (novel)|One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest]]''<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2006-11-02/ Frazz 11-02-2006]</ref> *A [[Tralfamadorian]] from ''[[Slaughterhouse Five]]''<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2007-10-31/ Frazz 10-31-2007]</ref> *[[Mildred Montag]] from ''[[Fahrenheit 451]]''<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2008-10-31/ Frazz 10-31-2008]</ref> *[[List_of_Catch-22_characters#Other_characters|Lt. Mudd]] a/k/a "the dead man in [[Yossarian|Yossarian's]] tent" from ''[[Catch-22]]''<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2009-10-26&DateBefore=2009-10-30&Order=d.DateStrip+ASC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=25&y=15 Frazz 10-3-/09]</ref> *The [[Devil]] from ''[[Faust]]'', specifically [[Randy Newman's Faust]]<ref>[[Randy Newman's Faust|Frazz Oct 26-29, 2010]]</ref>
'''Miss Jane Plainwell''' — The first-grade teacher at Bryson Elementary, and Frazz's romantic interest.<ref>[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,705271803,00.html "Comics for the young at heart", ''Deseret News'' (Salt Lake City) (December 21, 2008)]</ref> The students all think they'd be a perfect couple, and the two often go on jogs together while talking about life and love. Like Frazz, Miss Plainwell is also an athlete, running in 5K charity races. She inspired Mr. Burke to exercise more often, and trained and ran with him in the Detroit 5K. She majored in journalism, and worked at the sports department of a newspaper, before she decided to teach at Bryson Elementary, wanting to work with a "more mature audience."<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2002-09-19/ Frazz 9-19-2002]</ref> Miss Plainwell is modeled on Mallett's wife.<ref name = Enquirer>[http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2004/01/04/tem_tem1comicb.html "Here's a look at the five new comics joining our pages", ''Cincinnati Enquirer'' (January 24, 2004)]</ref> She has a pet [[greyhound]] named "Mario", which she adopted after it retired from racing.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2007-04-27&DateBefore=2007-04-28&Order=d.DateStrip+DESC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=16&y=11 Frazz April 27-28, 2008]</ref>
'''Mr. Burke''' — Mr. Burke is the fourth-grade teacher at Bryson Elementary, the best teacher there and Frazz's best friend.<ref name = Chronicle>[http://chronicle.augusta.com/stories/092902/fea_223-1548.000.shtml "'Frazz' takes readers back to school", ''Augusta Chronicle'' (September 29, 2002)]</ref> His one-on-one [[basketball]] matches with Frazz are filled with brilliant discussionsâand very little scoring.<ref name = Guzman>[http://www.mysanantonio.com/life/30849529.html Guzman, Rene, "'Frazz' sweeps through the comics with cool smarts", ''San Antonio Express News'' (October 11, 2008)]</ref> Burke started out obese, but has slimmed down due to a Frazz-inspired exercise program. He is revealed by the students to have had an Afro during high school.
'''Mrs. Olsen''' — Mrs. Olsen is the third grade teacher at Bryson Elementary, and the teacher from hell.<ref name = Chronicle/> She is frequently the object of tricks and practical jokes by Frazz and Caulfield.,<ref name = LATimes/> and Caulfield's questions/comments in class often drive her to distraction. She had enough of Frazz when he was her student years ago, and would just as soon he leave for good.<ref name = Guzman/> Another side of her character is seen when Caulfield gets a summer job in her garden (a summer 2005 sequence in ''Frazz'') and they come to have a sense of respect for each other. She is a composite of several of Mallett's teachers and one of Mallett's wife's teachers. She has a brother or sister, as she also has a niece. She is also of Scandinavian (probably Norwegian) descent, as she once cooked [[lutefisk]] for her class, in much the same way that Mrs. Trevino cooks gorditas on Cinco de Mayo.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
'''Mr. Spaetzle''' — The principal of Bryson Elementary.<ref name = Chronicle/> He craves the adoration the students heap on Frazz, and wants to be just like him. He wore nerdy glasses all throughout high school.<ref name = Guzman/>
'''Coach Hacker''' — The physical education teacher, interested only in team sports, with no interest in participatory athletics.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} Coach Hacker was an All-Big 10 defensive end in the 1970s,<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-09-25/ Frazz Sep 25, 2001] In a later strip, hoever, Coach Hacker is described as having been an all-conference defensive end for fictional "Southern State", and having played in the [[Cherry Bowl]]. The Cherry Bowl existed for two seasons in 1984 and 1985.[http://comics.com/frazz/2009-09-27/ Frazz Sept 27, 2009]</ref> but now is out-of shape and has been married five times. In college his nickname was "Man-O-War", but now it is "Jellyfish".<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-06-18/ Frazz 6-18-2001]</ref><ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2001-09-25&DateBefore=2001-09-26&Order=d.DateStrip+DESC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=55&y=5 Frazz Sept 24-25, 2001]</ref> According to Mallett, he "doesn't understand Frazz any more than he understands how to work a combination lock".<ref name = Guzman/> He is said to have eaten at Burger Bunker every single day for years. He is often very competitive with Frazz, comparing sports such as football and hockey against running and cycling.
'''Mr. Uhrmann''' — A substitute teacher for Mrs. Olsen who is unflustered by Caulfield. He is described by Frazz as the only one of Caulfield's substitute teachers not to "throw up his hands and quit by 9:30". Caulfield calls him "The Uhrmanator".<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2003-02-17&DateBefore=2003-02-22&Order=d.DateStrip+DESC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=13&y=8 Frazz Feb 17-22, 2003]</ref>
'''Mrs. Trevino''' — The second-grade teacher at Bryson Elementary. She cooks gorditas for her class every [[Cinco de Mayo]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2003-05-05/ Frazz 5-5-2003]</ref> She also had "Tamale Day" to use cooking as a teaching tool (although she apparently didn't know that the corn husk was not to be eaten). This causes her to garner quite a bit of jealousy from Mrs. Olsen, who thinks that her native country's food is just as interesting as gorditas. Mrs. Trevino has been phased away from the strip, as has Clutch, now that Ms. Plainwell (Mrs. Trevino's former best friend) and Frazz are now in a relationship.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2001-09-11&DateBefore=2001-09-14&Order=d.DateStrip+DESC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=18&y=6 Frazz Sept 11-14, 2001]</ref>
'''Clutch''' — Frazz's friend & fellow runner/cyclist. Works as an [[emergency room]] [[nurse]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-07-30/ Frazz July 30 â Aug. 11, 2001]</ref>
==References to real life== Many of the characters or locations in the strip are references to real-life people whom Mallett respects or other aspects of his life. In addition to various literary figures, among these references are the following:
*In a 2008 interview, Mallett said that Bryson Elementary is named after one of his favorite authors, [[Bill Bryson]].<ref>[http://www.ileach.co.uk/post/jef_mallett/jef.html#top Palmer, Brian, "Washing Machine Post: The Jef Mallett Interview" ''Ileach'' (May 3, 2008)]</ref> *Frazz plays catch with Caulfield on Bobke's Bluff, referencing cyclist [[Bob Roll]].<ref>[http://velonews.com/article/6143 Barrringer, Marc, "Q&A; Cartoonist Jeff Mallett on 'Frazz'", ''VeloNews'', (May 23, 2004)]</ref> *Frazz keeps in his workshop pictures of cyclist Steve Larsen, [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] swimmer and triathlete [[Sheila Taormina]] and professional triathlete [[Tim DeBoom]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2003-11-16/ Frazz 11-16-2003]</ref> *Frazz often time wears t-shirts with logos. These logos come from all aspects of Jef Mallett's life. Bands he likes, restaurants, places he visited, inside jokes etc.
Jef Mallett lives and works in [[Lansing]], [[Michigan]]. The strip is set in a town named "Rodney", in a state beginning with the letter "M". While Mallett has not formally identified the state, he often drops Michigan references into his strips. Some of the location references include:
*In one of the earliest strips, Caulfield lists his address on a form as 3310 Sycamore Street, Rodney, M. The second letter of the state abbreviation cannot be seen.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2001-04-10/ Frazz 04-10-2001]</ref> While playing with two children, Frazz runs to a city limits sign for "Rodney - Home of Bryson Elementary".<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2003-11-02/ Frazz 11--2-2003]</ref> The town of [[Rodney, Michigan|Rodney]] is located near Mallett's home town of [[Big Rapids]], although it does not have a Sycamore Street.<ref>[http://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&q=Rodney&um=1&ie=UTF-8&sa=N&tab=wl Rodney, MI at Google Maps]</ref> *One of the children tells Frazz and Miss Plainwell that she saw them the previous evening at [[Zingerman's]] in [[Ann Arbor]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2004-01-24/ Frazz 1-24-2004]</ref> *Caulfield sings [[parody]] lyrics to [[O Little Town of Bethlehem]] referencing [[Twelve Oaks Mall]] in [[Novi, Michigan|Novi]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2004-12-25/ Frazz 12-25-2004]</ref> *In October 2007, Frazz trains to run in the Motor City Marathon, and Miss Plainwell coaches Mr. Burke to run in the 5K,<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2007-10-10/ Frazz 10-10-2007]</ref> in [[Detroit]] and [[Windsor, Ontario]] while Mallett was training to run in the same race, his first marathon.<ref>[http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071018/SPORTS18/310180001 Kurtis, Doug, "Running: First-time marathoners speak out", ''Detroit Free Press'' (October 18, 2007)]</ref> *Caulfield tells Frazz that Mrs. Olsen believes reports that [[Elvis Presley|Elvis]] was seen working as a [[barista]] at the Water Street Coffee Joint in [[Kalamazoo]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2008-01-19/ Frazz 1-19-2008]</ref><ref>[http://www.mlive.com/business/index.ssf/2008/01/frazz_features_kalamazoo_coffe.html Parikh, Jane, ""'Frazz' features Kalamazoo coffee shop", ''Kalamazoo Gazette''(January 18, 2008) ]</ref> On May 1, 2011, Caulfield reported a similar sighting when he tells Frazz that Mrs. Olsen said that Elvis works in the [[Caribou Coffee]] shop in [[Royal Oak, Michigan|Royal Oak]].<ref>[http://www.comics.com/frazz/2011-05-01 May 1, 2011 Frazz strip at Comics.com] Retrieved 2011-05-01</ref> *Mrs. Olsen asks Frazz to help with her car which got stuck in the snow. After he agrees, and discovers that her car isn't in the school parking lot, she tells him that her car is in [[Detroit]], behind a casino.<ref name=Watson/><ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2008-02-26&DateBefore=2008-02-28&Order=d.DateStrip+DESC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=29&y=14/ Frazz Feb 26-28, 2008]</ref> *Coach Hacker says that people in [[Lake Odessa]] talked for years about how (fictional) Clugston College beat [[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]].<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2008-05-05/ Frazz 5-5-08]</ref> *Caulfield answers "N/A" to a math story problem asking how long it would take to drive 28 miles from [[Novi, Michigan|Novi]] to [[Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport|the airport]] at the speed limit, arguing "Who goes the speed limit on [[Interstate 275 (Michigan)|I-275]]?"<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2008-12-02/ Frazz 12-02-2008]</ref> *Caulfield and Frazz overlook a winter skyline<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2009-01-03/ Frazz 1--3-2009]</ref> featuring the three smokestacks from the [[Lansing Board of Water and Light]] [[Lansing Board of Water and Light#Electric Utility|Eckert Power Station]], and a fourth topped by the "worlds largest lugnut"<ref>Godfrey, Linda, ''Weird Michigan'' Sterling Publishing Company, Inc., 2006 ISBN 1-4027-3907-9, 9781402739071 p151</ref> across from [[Cooley Law School Stadium]], both located in [[Lansing]]. *Frazz gives a motorist directions, telling him to take [[M-115 (Michigan highway)|M-115]] to [[M-22 (Michigan highway)|M-22]] around [[Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore|the Sleeping Bear Dunes]], taking him a few hundred miles out of his way.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2009-03-28/ Frazz 3-28-09]</ref> *One of the students describes a game involving altering bar code price tags at [[Meijer|Thrifty Acres]], the [[Walker, Michigan]] - based regional hypermarket chain.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2010-03-21/ Frazz 3-21-10]</ref> *Frazz wears a t-shirt with the M-1, or Woodward Ave, sign on it. * At the Motorcity Marathon, Jane Plainwell is carrying a bag with the Dances With Dirt logo (DWD), which is a trail ultra series that originated in [[Hell, MI]]. * Frazz and another character discuss "the I-96 overpass", referencing [[Interstate 96]], a highway solely within Michigan.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2011-05-21/ Frazz 5-21-11]</ref> * Frazz and a Bryson student discuss the "big game ... between State and the U ..." on the day the [[Michigan State University]] (State) and the [[University of Michigan]] (U) are playing [[American football|football]] in [[East Lansing]]. This is the big [[Paul Bunyan Trophy|intrastate rivalry]] and the first time in years they are considered evenly matched.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2011-10-15/ Frazz 15-10-11]</ref>
==Comparisons to ''Calvin and Hobbes''== Because of similarities in calligraphic style, Frazz's physical appearance, his station in life as a brilliant underachiever, and his age relative to Calvin of ''[[Calvin and Hobbes]]'', speculation arose that Mallett was actually [[Bill Watterson]], or that ''Frazz'' was an unauthorized [[sequel]] to Watterson's strip and that Frazz is Calvin as an adult. Some other characters that are similar are Miss Wormwood and Rosalyn in Watterson's strip to Mrs. Olsen and Miss Plainwell in Mallett's strip. In a May 2006 series of strips, Frazz and Caulfield invent a game called "Bedlamball" that, like "Calvinball", has no apparent rules or scoring.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/?DateAfter=2006-05-01&DateBefore=2006-05-04&Order=d.DateStrip+DESC&PerPage=10&Search=&x=47&y=8 Frazz May 1-4, 2006]</ref> Mallett acknowledges Watterson's influence, but denies that he is Watterson or that Frazz is intended as a copy or replacement of, or sequel to, ''Calvin and Hobbes''.<ref>[http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/514066.html Ehlers, Matt, "Jeff Mallett: 'Frazz'", ''The News & Observer'' (November 24, 2006) ]</ref>
In his online column, "Chatological Humor", ''[[Washington Post]]'' columnist [[Gene Weingarten]] published a response by Mallett to the speculation that Frazz was a grown-up Calvin.<ref>[http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A18245-2005Jan18.html Weingarten, Gene, "Chatological Humor", ''WashingtonPost.com'' (January 28, 2005)]</ref> In the foreword to ''Live at Bryson Elementary'', Weingarten writes, "They're [critics are] focusing not only on hair (Frazz's frizz), but also on his station in life: a brilliant underachiever. Well, Jef assures me that any similarity is unintentional."
''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' columnist Charles Solomon said, "The humor and calligraphic drawing in âFrazzâ reflect Wattersonâs influence, but the strip doesnât feel like a pallid imitation."<ref name = LATimes>[http://articles.latimes.com/2005/oct/09/books/bk-solomon9 Solomon, Charles, "The unforgettable, irreplaceable Calvin", LA Times Book Review (October 9, 2005) p.R-6]</ref>
Mallett has alluded to the speculation several times in the strip. In a September 2003 Sunday strip an introverted student tells Frazz that she wants to be famous, and believes it is possible to be famous for one's work, without exposing your private life to the public eye. Frazz says, "Good point. Like J.D. Salinger or Bill Watterson." She says she's never heard of them.<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2003-09-21/ Frazz 9-21-2003]</ref> As part of a brief story arc in November 2006, Frazz tells Caulfield "I also used to be Bill Watterson's personal assistant."<ref>[http://comics.com/frazz/2006-11-29/ Frazz 11-29-2006]</ref>
==Awards== *2003 and 2005 Wilbur Award for Promoting Ethics and Positive Values
==Anthologies== *''Live at Bryson Elementary''. 2005, Andrews McMeel Publishing. 128 pages. Includes foreword by [[Gene Weingarten]] and introduction by Jef Mallett. ISBN 0-7407-5447-5 *''99% Perspiration''. 2006, Andrews McMeel Publishing. 128 pages. ISBN 0-7407-6043-2 *''Frazz 3.1416''. 2008, Andrews McMeel Publishing. 128 pages. ISBN 0-7407-7739-4. Includes an introduction by [[Charles Solomon]]
